text: (clanging, cracking, sizzling)
- Hello, and welcome back to Sorted Food.

Today, two of our normal
home cooks, Barry and Jamie,

are going head to head
in a blind taste test.
We're gonna ask them,
can they pick the premium ingredient?
Yes, it's a competition,

but also, hopefully, we'll
all learn a little bit more

about where perhaps it's
best to spend our money.

- But mainly, it's a competition
that I'm here to win.
- And you're gonna be very well-fed.
There are some beautiful dishes coming up.
Bring on round one.
(upbeat music)

This is how it works,
you've got a blindfold,
you've got A and B in front of you.
Both have been prepared

with identical quantities
and ingredients and method,
with one exception.
That's the one we want you to pick out,

and then we want you to
pick out the premium.
- Got nothing.
Oh, there's something there.
- Looks beautiful. And how does it taste?
- Ooh.

Uh-uh.
- Ah!
(mimics gargling)
- It's like a satay sauce,
with some vermicelli noodles?
- Ooh!
So far very, very good.

There's also a little thing
on a stick on the plate
if you want to try that.

- It's quite heavy.
(laughs)
- Ooh.

- [Ben] Please don't stab
yourself. It's on a stick.
- What!

- You know I like
putting things on sticks.

- Why would you give

I'm blindfolded!
- I'm liking this dish. Brilliant!

- Try B, see if there's anything
that stands out different.

This is perhaps typically
a street food item anyway.

- Oh, that's just chilli.

Ah!

might be stay less sweet, more chunky.

what we made was a marinade
with peanut butter, coconut milk,

and then a whole bunch of
wonderful fragrant spices.

So yes, lemon grass,
galangal, garlic, chilli.

And then, once that had
been put over the chicken,
we also use the leftover marinade
with water and fried onions,

cook it all down into a
sauce that we then blended.
- B feels like it's richer.

It's got more flavour
attached to it essentially.

- I always try my best to
buy a premium peanut butters,
but if I'm deadly honest,

I think I prefer the cheaper
ones for nostalgic reasons.
So I'm preferring the taste of A to B.
So therefore, I think B is the premium.

put the two peanut butters
in front of you.
You can remove the blindfold.
You're not allowed to change your mind,
you've locked in your answer.
But would you?

- I think I'm right, because
A does look more oily,

which I'd assume it to
be more, to be cheaper.

- I feel like when I've seen

they've been a bit coarser,

like as in whole grain peanut
butter, that kind of thing.
Neither of these have given me that.
- You are wrong.
(buzzer ringing)
- Damn!
- [Both] Really?
- A is Manilife peanut butter.

Organic, but also made with
99% peanuts, just 1% salt.
Whereas B is a basic, in this case,
Sainsbury's crunchy peanut butter.
87% roasted peanuts,
but then other ingredients,
rapeseed oil, palm oil, sugar, and salt.

- Maybe that's why I was
getting more flavour from them,

because it's got the
sugar and the oils in it.
- The difference and the dish themselves
are a lot more subtle
than eating the peanut butter straight.

- And there was very
slightly, very, very slightly,

more caramelization of the

with the one that had
the high sugar content.

- Oh, right.
- Very subtle.
The basic version is 25p per 100g.
How much do you think that Manilife
premium peanut butter is?
- Another 10p, 35p.
- Pound?
just over five times the price.

- We're still just talking
about blitzed up peanuts?

- You're talking about a

and you're also talking about
a higher quality of peanut

- I think that's worth it.

I think peanut butter falls
into one of those categories
where it should cost more than it does,

and it should cost more
than we expect it to.
- I like peanut butter. I don't love it.
If I loved it,

I'd probably go to every
degree to get the best I can.

But for when I use it,
which is very rarely,

I'd probably just still
stick with something
a little bit cheaper.

- Okay, A is more silky.
- A is definitely sort of crumblier.
- B is more bitty and crumbly,
which is more like a goat's cheese.
- B is the premium.
- B is the premium.
- Are you looking in the answer B?
- Yes, Ben!
- Okay, blindfold off.
You've looked in B as your premium,
you can't change your mind.

- Oh.
- But would you?
- Did make a mess, didn't I? look at this.

round, the premium is B.
You're correct.

- Yay!
- (grunts) Come on!

Needed that.
- Okay, cool.
- So, both pretty good.
A is a PDO status feta from Sainsbury.

So it still has that protected
designation of origin.

Whereas B is Epiros feta from

and is our premium.
- B is definitely creamier.

There is more going on in
that mouth full of cheese

then there is A, which is
slightly more one dimensional.

as made from herbacious

happen there traditionally
for an awful long time.

guns. It's all in the funk.
That's just salty cheese.

How much per kilo for the premium?
- £10 per kilo.
- That's quite a lot really, isn't it?
- so, it's almost three times the price.
- Yeah, that's quite a lot.
- That's a very, very nice feta,
but not three times the price.
- But to spend £4 on a pack of feta,
that's all right.
If I'm getting really good stuff for that,
I might get slightly less of it.
- So as opposed to £1.50?
- Yeah.
- Certainly a strong cheese.

It's salty, it's got all

that we use quite a
lot in midweek cooking,
'cause it gives it a real lift,

and therefore, actually a
little bit does go a long way.

A and B.

Identical in preparation with

- Ah.
- Oh, that's very unfortunate.

That's sort of supposed to

- Oh!
(laughter)
- Ooh, wow!
That is wonderful.
A sweet chickpea cassoulet of sorts.
(laughter)
Really sweet tangy sauce.
- Hmm, calamari.
- It's very similar. Yeah.

I'm gonna put you out of
your misery, it's cuttlefish.
But you know, same kind of family

and it behaves in a similar
way when you're blindfolded.
Try B. (chuckles)
- Oh.
(stammering) It's not the chickpeas.
- Ebbers, is it chickpeas?
- [Ben] You've spotted the difference.

It's the only thing in
the dish that's changed.
You are judging the chickpeas.
- They're like pumpkin-sized chickpeas.

- (laughs) Not that big, but
yes, they are slightly bigger.
- This is interesting,

'cause I use chickpeas quite
a lot at home from a tin
and they are cheap.
- You can't really taste chickpeas
when they're covered in everything else.

They're just there for texture
and bantz, aren't they?
- Bantz, yep. Okay, fine, yep.
- Well, I think both of these
are bigger chickpeas than normal.
- A, they're slightly smaller,

and they've got a bit
more of a bite to them.
Sounds silly, but B, they taste fresher.

They seem plumper and a much
more of a velvety texture
as you bite through it.
I'm gonna say that B's the premium.
- I'm gonna have to go with B, Ebbers,
'cause they're massive.
And there's no way that smaller ones
would be more premium, is there?
- And you can whip your blindfold off.

You've locked in B, you
can't change your mind,
but would you?

- Nope.
- Yes.
I did say B and I presume that is right,
because they are not in a tin.

- Looking at the packaging,
I would say that I'm right.

- I can confirm you are absolutely
right, B is the premium.

- Okay, brilliant.
- Hey.

- So A is Ocado's, kind of
their basic chickpea range.
Italian chickpeas.
B is the premium.

They are Brindisa's
Spanish chickpeas, jarred,

but they are also cooked a
lot slower and more gentle.

And they're kind of
more tender, more plump,

and actually almost
richer once they end up...
Almost creamier in their final result.

In each dish, we've used
the liquid they come in
to help cook in the chickpeas stew,

along with smoked paprika,
some other flavours,
some aioli and some cuttlefish.
- [Jamie] It's like somebody's already
half whisked up your aquafaba.

- And it's very possible that
the preservation process,
so storing in a jar as opposed to a tin,

which obviously has to
be heated to seal it,
would make a difference as well.
And finally, B is also organic.
- I think the difference here as well
is I buy tin chickpeas to bulk out a meal,

whereas these chickpeas, they
are, in a tapas kind of style,
that's the hero of the dish.
You don't need the fish on top of that.
- I think, in a dish like this,
it's very easy to notice the difference.
Just in the size of the chickpeas.

Suddenly, the chickpeas
become a talking point.
- This is true.

Tender, nutty, kind of more
creamy in their consistency.

If I was to tell you that
the basic version is 14,
1-4 pence per 100g,

how much do you reckon
for the Brindisa ones?

Which is a family brand, it's
been around through 1960s,

it's still the children,
grandchildren that produce them.
- I'm gonna say 90p.
- 70p per 100g.
so more than seven times the price.
- I can justify that in its flavouring.

Can I justify that when
buying that at home?

For what I use chickpeas
for, probably not.
- I think it depends on usage,

because it was instantly
noticeable in this dish for me.

And if I was gonna
create something special,

then I'd want to use the
best chickpeas I could find.

- Enough of a difference for you
to able to pick the premium.

Well done.
